Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: Stakeholders expect a working prototype soon to secure internal approval
Expectation2: Organize and lead religious education classes for children and adults
Situation2: The initial planning meeting for the next season's adult faith formation series is on the calendar.
Story: I stared at my calendar, heart pounding. The engineering team’s group chat buzzed with messages—stakeholders wanted a working prototype by next week, and my manager’s tone was clear: this was make-or-break for the project. I was supposed to be finalizing the design specs, troubleshooting the last bugs, and preparing a demo. Every minute counted. But at the same time, my phone vibrated with a reminder: tonight was the planning meeting for the adult faith formation series at church. As the priest, I was expected to lead, to inspire, to lay out a vision for the coming season. The parish council and the catechists would be looking to me for guidance and energy. I could picture the faces of the adults who’d be attending, hoping for something meaningful. I felt pulled in two directions—my mind racing with circuit diagrams and lesson plans, my heart heavy with the knowledge that I couldn’t give my best to both. The pressure from my engineering team and the trust of my parishioners pressed in on me, and I sat frozen, torn between two worlds that both needed all of me.
